content: The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" aims to provide guidance to Federal and State bank regulators for ensuring that banks can offer loans and ongoing liquidity to home builders. It also seeks to enable banks to provide credit to aid in restoring liquidity to the home building sector and revitalizing the residential housing market. The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" requires Federal banking agencies to coordinate rulemaking for financial institutions making real estate loans to home builders, eliminating the 100 percent bank capital measurement restriction. The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" allows qualified financial institutions with a CAMEL composite rating of 1, 2, or 3 to provide real estate loans to home builders with viable projects. Federal banking agencies must ensure realistic market-based appraisals for collateral valuation in real estate loans. The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" requires financial institutions to use realistic market-based appraisals for collateral valuation in real estate loans. Federal banking agencies mandate the use of arms length transactions for assessing underwriting standards and collateral values for real estate loans. The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" mandates realistic market-based appraisals for collateral valuation in real estate loans. Federal banking agencies must use arms length transactions to assess underwriting standards and collateral values for real estate loans. Financial institutions are not compelled to call or curtail real estate loans of home builders in good standing. If a home builder's collateral decreases in value, the institution can work with the builder to realize the maximum market valuation. The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" requires realistic market-based appraisals for collateral valuation in real estate loans. Workout methods can be used for up to 24 months after final regulations are issued. Financial institutions must exhaust all workout methods before charging off a real estate loan. The appropriate Federal banking agency cannot force a financial institution to reclassify a real estate loan on its balance sheet unless necessary. The "Home Construction Lending Regulatory Improvement Act of 2011" mandates realistic appraisals for real estate loans. Financial institutions must exhaust workout methods before charging off a loan. Improved CAMEL ratings can take effect 24 months after final regulations are issued. Agencies must coordinate for consistency. The agencies with authorities under the Act must consult and coordinate to ensure consistent regulations. Within 6 months of the Act's enactment, final regulations must be issued. Federal banking agencies will enforce the rules for financial institutions. State laws will not be overridden unless they conflict with the Act's rules. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "appropriate Federal banking agency" is defined as in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. An "arms length transaction" refers to a real estate transaction between independent buyer and seller. The term excludes short sales, foreclosed properties, or distressed real estate. "As completed valuation" is the estimated market value of collateral after full development completion. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to financial institutions, good standing, and real estate loans, including the purpose of real estate loans for land acquisition and development. The curr_chunk provides definitions related to real estate projects, total capital, viable projects, and workout methods for preventing real estate loan defaults.
